sample.value: A total of 200 HITS are created on Amazon Mechanical Turk. The sample size has been decided due to budgetary restrictions.

analyses.value: We will run a panel probit regression to estimate our main hypothesis. The trials create a 25-times repeated measure with accept/forego bonus as the dependent variable in each trial. The independent variables is the assignment to the experimental condition.

outliers.value: We will exclude all participants who fail to correctly the control question.

dependent.value: The dependent variable consists of 25 decisions made by the participants. In each decision, the participant faces a trade-off between a financial reward (i.e., a bonus-opportunity on Mturk) that comes with actual CO2 emissions and foregoing the reward while avoiding the emission. The trials vary in bonus height and amount of CO2 emissions (5x5, fully crossed).

conditions.value: The participants will be assigned to one of only two conditions, high versus low descriptive norm information. In each condition, the participants are asked to estimate the share (out of 100) of participants making the sustainable decision. The question is answered on a three point scale with a midpoint that is either high (75-85 people) or low (5-15 people). It is expected that the manipulation creates a difference in beliefs about the average behavior of other people.

hypothesis.value: The main research questions is whether information about descriptive norms shifts sustainability behavior. The hypothesis is that exposure to selective information about low versus high descriptive norms creates differences in behavior. Exposure to high descriptive social norms will lead to more sustainable behavior compared to exposure to low descriptive social norms.

name.value: Social norms, self-control, and sustainable behavior (Study 1)

other.value: We will also run an analysis based on the number of sustainable decisions (cross-sectional data), based on average sustainability behavior.

sample.value: A total of 200 HITS are created on Amazon Mechanical Turk. The sample size has been decided due to budgetary restrictions.

analyses.value: We will run a panel probit regression to estimate our main hypothesis. The trials create a 25-times repeated measure with accept/forego bonus as the dependent variable in each trial. The independent variables are the assignment to the experimental condition, self-control, and the interaction thereof. Environmental attitudes (NEP-R), climate change beliefs (3-item measure), and demographic variables will be entered intro regression models as robustness checks.

outliers.value: We will exclude all participants who fail to correctly the control question.

dependent.value: The dependent variable consists of 25 decisions made by the participants. In each decision, the participant faces a trade-off between a financial reward (i.e., a bonus-opportunity on Mturk) that comes with actual CO2 emissions and foregoing the reward while avoiding the emission. The trials vary in bonus height and amount of CO2 emissions (5x5, fully crossed).

conditions.value: The participants will be assigned to one of only two conditions, high versus low descriptive norm information. In each condition, the participants are asked to estimate the share (out of 100) of participants making the sustainable decision. The question is answered on a three point scale with a midpoint that is either high (75-85 people) or low (5-15 people). It is expected that the manipulation creates a difference in beliefs about the average behavior of other people. Self-control will serve as a moderator that is assessed after the behavior.

hypothesis.value: The main research questions is whether trait self-control moderates the impact of social norms on sustainable behavior. The hypothesis is that high trait self-control increases the impact of the effect of social norms on sustainable decision making. Exposure to high descriptive social norms will lead to more sustainable behavior compared to exposure to low descriptive social norms and this effect is stronger for people high (versus low) in self-control.

attributes.title: Memory attack by semantic mediator: causing retroactive interference via Deese-Roediger-McDermott lists

q1.value: Semantic similarity and retroactive interference with delay

q3.value: This is identical to the first two experiments, except that here we are imposing a one-hour delay before the final test. We predict similar results of retroactive spatial memory impairments.

q4.value: Like in our first previous studies, we hypothesize that semantic similarity in a retroactive interference context will impair spatial memory retrieval, this time with a one hour delay before test. We will power this study to the same degree (N=112; see previous versions on this page).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a within-subject design. All subjects will be exposed to the experimental (related words shown in Phase 2) and control (related words not shown in Phase 2) conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will use undergraduate students taking this for course credit or extra credit. We hope to be done with the study by the end of January 2020, depending on how quickly we can reach 112 subjects.

q13.value: N=112 based on a power analysis from the previous study. There may or may not be more subjects, depending on how quickly and how many sign-ups there are at once, but we will stop recruiting once N=112 is reached.

q14.value: This is an identical power analysis from the previous study to reach beta=0.8 at alpha=0.05.

q15.value: We will stop collecting sign-ups once N = 112 is reached.

question.value: We are manipulating whether or not spatial memories (for words) will have semantically related content presented in a prior phase.

These measures are identical to the previous versions. For the main finding, we will measure spatial memory accuracy based on whether or centrally presented words are dragged to the correct, learned location. We will also measure recognition as in the previous version.

We will use t-tests to address the main question of spatial recall and recognition, as in the previous experiments and the current version of the code. We will also run a bootstrapping procedure using backward and forward associative strength to look at the effects of these variables on our main effects of spatial impairment, as in the previous experiments and the current version of the code.

q21.value: We will make inferences based on the P-value of the mixed-effects model.

q24.value: If we do find an effect of semantic similarity, we will explore the role of awareness of the relatedness of the words in phase 1 and 2, as in previous versions. We will also look at backward and forward associative strength, as mentioned above.

attributes.title: The role of goal meaning in behavioural procrastination

q1.value: The role of goal meaning in behavioural procrastination

q2.value: Sisi Yang, Fuschia Sirois, Claudia C. von Bastian, Peter Totterdell

q3.value:
Procrastination is a form of self-regulation failure that reflects the prioritization of short-mood regulation over long-term goal achievement. Recent theory and research argues that an inability to regulate negative emotions in a healthy and nonself-defeating way plays a key role in understanding why people procrastinate (Sirois & Pychyl, 2013; Tice & Bratslavsky, 2000). Appraisal theories of emotion point out that one’s specific emotional reaction results from their subjective appraisal of an event (i.e. its meaning and significance of an event) rather than the event itself (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984; Scherer, 1988). An emotion regulation strategy known as cognitive reappraisal, a primary form of cognitive change, entails using cognitive and linguistic processes to reinterpret the meaning of a situation (Jazaieri et al., 2014), which is effective for downregulating negative emotions (Gross & John, 2003). Yet to date, there is little (if any) research directly testing whether cognitive reappraisal, interprets and assigns meaning to an event or potential stressor in particular, influences procrastination. In the present research we aim to address this gap by investigating how reappraising aversive tasks in light of personal meaning influences task-related emotions and subsequent behavioural procrastination.

Given that meaningfulness is strongly associated with positive emotions (Miao & Gan, 2018), in order to investigate the role of personal meaning on procrastinating behaviour but rule out the possibility that any effects from the meaning making manipulation are not simply due to increases in positive affect, comparing effect sizes of these two factors (i.e. personal meaning and positive emotions) on behavioural procrastination are needed.  

In addition, one common belief about the nature of procrastination is that it is linked to setting excessively high standards. Researchers have asserted that procrastination is closely correlated to perfectionism (e.g. Flett, Blankstein, Hewitt, & Koledin, 1992; Stöber & Joormann, 2001). More specifically, from a multi-dimensional perspective, a recent meta-analysis revealed that trait procrastination is positively associated with perfectionistic concerns, and negatively associated with perfectionistic strivings (Sirois, Molnar, & Hirsch, 2017). The question of whether perfectionism influences personal meaning or positive affect associated with goals and subsequent procrastination has, however, not been investigated.

q4.value:
1) Participants in the personal meaning group will engage in less procrastination than those in the control group; 
2) Participants in the positive feelings group will procrastinate less than those in the control group but will procrastinate more than those in the personal meaning group.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
An experimental design will be used to test whether increased personal meaning of an aversive goal plays a role in subsequent behavioural procrastination. 
Participants will be randomized via Qualtrics to three groups: personal meaning group, positive affect group and control group.
Mechanisms of change (i.e. the levels of positive and negative affect, personal meaning of an aversive task) will be collected before the manipulation (pretest) and after manipulation (posttest) to obtain pre and post-test levels. Behavioural procrastination will be assessed 36-48 hours after the completion of the manipulation.

q9.value: Randomization will be used to allocate participants into three groups (i.e. a personal meaning group, positive feeling group or control group), resulting in equal sample sizes. Participants will be assigned into one of three conditions using a survey flow randomization option within Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be invited by e-mail and online adverts to participate in a study about the subjective experiences of goal pursuit. Individuals who are working on an important goal, are aged 18 and over will qualify to participate. 

The initial survey 

Those who are interested in taking part, will be asked to click on a hyperlink to the Qualtrics survey web address, which will provide information about the study including the purpose of the study, the procedures participants would need to follow during the study, and what to do in case of problems or queries. After providing consent, participants will be asked to click the “I agree” button if they consent to participate.  

After linking to the online study via Qualtrics, all participants will be asked to complete a demographics questionnaire (age, gender, educational level and ethnicity) and the same set of baseline questionnaires (pretest). The baseline measures include 
The 9-item General Procrastination Scale (GPS-9; Sirois, Yang, & Van Eerde, 2019); the 5-item Personal Meaning Questionnaire (MILQ; Steger, Frazier, Oishi, & Kaler, 2006); the 10-item Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS; Mackinnon , Jorm, Christensen, Korten, Jacomb, & Rodgers, 1999); the 15-item Multidimensional Perfectionism Scale (MPS, Hewitt, Habke, Lee-Baggley, Sherry, & Flett, 2008).

Afterward, they will be instructed to list their most important current goal that they are struggling with. Specifically, in order to maximise the chance that they will procrastinate on a goal, we emphasised in the instructions that “it is better to list a goal that you are averse to and struggling with but need to complete.” 

In order to manipulate personal meaning, we will follow the procedures used in a study of expressive writing (King & Miner, 2000; Rubin, Boals, & Klein, 2010).
All participants will be randomized to either a personal meaning group, positive feeling group, or control group, and will complete condition-specific sets of statements.

Participants in the personal meaning group will be asked to think about the meaningful aspects of their intended goal, for example “Completing this goal will be valuable to how I see myself, because ______________________________.”
Participants in the positive affect group will be asked to write about something that made them happy, for example “Completing this goal will make me feel happy, because________________________.”
Participants in the control group will be asked to think about what they did yesterday, for example “I woke up to an alarm clock at________________________.”
Lastly, all participants will be presented with the meaning in life questionnaire (MILQ), the 10-item Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS) again. 
The follow-up survey

Participants will be contacted approximately 36-48 hours following their completion of the original survey via e-mail and invited to complete the follow-up survey. 
Their tasks will be to write down their chosen goal that they listed in the first part of the study, to complete a measure that assesses whether they procrastinated on their goal during the day following their participation, as well as to rate their emotional state (PANAS) and levels of personal meaning (MILQ). To measure procrastinating behaviour, participants will be asked to complete a grid that divides their past day (from 9am to 11pm) in 20-minute time intervals. A total of 42 intervals will be presented to participants at the same time. They will be asked to report what they were doing during each interval and indicate whether they were delaying or avoiding doing something they had intended to do once they recorded their activity at each interval. Any interval was indicated as “delay” will be counted as procrastination intervals and summed into reflecting the number of minutes spent procrastinating. This method of measuring behavioural procrastination was used in a previous study (Sirois & Giguère, 2018). Participants who successfully complete the initial and the follow up survey will have the option of being entered into a prize draw to win a £50 (or equivalent) Amazon voucher.

q13.value: The study aims to recruit a minimum of 246 participants (82 each group) to detect medium effect size of Cohen’s f=0.20 and a power of 0.80 for One-way ANOVA. Also, a minimum of 210 participants (70 per group) will be needed to detect medium effect size of Cohen’s d=0.20 and a power of 0.80 for two-tailed t-test independent-samples t-test. Additionally, accounting for a 10% attrition rate, we will, therefore, attempt to recruit up to 270 participants to account.

q14.value: The inclusion criteria for the study will be participants who are: age 18 or over and self-identify as having an important personal goal that they are working on but perceive as aversive.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated when N=270 participants have been recruited.

question.value:
Personal meaning will be manipulated with a writing task, where participants will be asked to will be asked to think about the meaningful aspects of their intended goal.
Participants in the positive feeling group will be asked to write about how the goal makes them happy.
The control group will receive a writing task where they will be asked to think about their routines the previous day.

See below for the script of each writing task:

Personal meaning group: 
For this next task, we would like you to think about the meaningful aspects of your goal, that is the ways your goal may have value for you.   
Please complete at least two of the following statements listed below about your goal, thinking about how meaningful different aspect are. In completing these statements please write as much as you can about the personal meaning of your goal. A good answer should include at least 1-2 sentences per statement.
An example statement is: “Completing this goal will be valuable to how I see myself, because                                                          .”  

Positive affect group: 
For this next task, we would like you to think about the aspects of your goal that make you happy. 
Please complete at least two of the following statements listed below about your goal, thinking about how the goal can make you happy. In completing these statements please write as much as you can about the positive feelings of your goal. A good answer should include at least 1-2 sentences per question. An example statement is “Completing this goal will make me feel happy, because                    .”

Control group: 
For this next task, we would like you to think about what you did yesterday. 
Please complete at least two of the following statements listed below about how you spent your time yesterday. Please write as much as you can about what you did yesterday. A good answer should include at least 1-2 sentences per question. An example statement is “I woke up to an alarm clock at                        .”

The initial survey will include a question for each of the following: age, gender, educational level and ethnicity. Following this, participants will be asked to complete the following scales: the 15-item Multidimensional Perfectionism Scale (MPS), the 9-item General Procrastination Scale (GPS-9), the 5-item Personal Meaning Questionnaire (MILQ); the 10-item Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS). MPS and GPS-9 score will serve as covariates because these traits are thought to affect procrastinating behaviour (e.g. (Burka & Yuen, 1983; Flett, Blankstein, Hewitt, & Koledin, 1992; Lay, 1986; Seo, 2008; Sirois et al., 2017; Stöber & Joormann, 2001). 


In the follow up survey, we will measure behavioural procrastination as the outcome variable, by asking participants to complete a grid that divides their past day (from 9am to 11 pm) in 20-minute time intervals. Any interval that was indicated as “delay” will be counted as an incident of procrastination. All intervals marked as procrastination will be summed up to reflect the number of minutes spent procrastinating.

We will use mean scores on the 9-items general procrastination scale (GPS-9), the personal meaning questionnaire (MILQ), the PANAS and the multidimensional perfectionism scale (MPS). The procrastination scores will sum the “delay “intervals into an index reflecting the number of minutes spent procrastinating.

1) Tests for normality

2) Descriptive analyses

We will use descriptive statistics on age, gender, education level and ethnicity in each group to summarize our sample data. A one-way ANOVA will be used to examine the distributions of age for each of the three groups to see whether the randomization was effective in balancing this variable across groups. When this is not the case, age will be used as a covariate in the hypothesis tests. 
A Chi-square test will be used to see whether gender/education level/ ethnicity affect personal meaning or positive affect in each group. 

3) Baseline equivalences
We will run a one-way ANOVA to see whether three groups are equivalent on key variables, including trait perfectionism, trait procrastination, personal meaning and positive affect. 

4) Manipulation check 
Two mixed ANOVAs will be conducted as manipulation checks to verify whether there is significant changes in personal meaning or positive affect from pretest to posttest within each of the respective experimental groups. In the first mixed ANOVA, the mean personal meaning score will serve as the dependent variable and condition (i.e. personal meaning / positive affects / control) will serve as the between-subjects independent variable, and time (pretest / posttest) will serve as within-subject factor. Likewise, the mean positive affect score will serve as the dependent variable in the second mixed ANOVA, condition will be the between-subjects, and time (pretest / posttest) will serve as within-subject independent variable.


5) Hypothesis tests
A one-way ANOVA will be conducted for the main hypothesis test. The summed procrastination score will serve as the dependent variable, and condition (i.e. personal meaning/positive affects/control) will serve as the between-subjects independent variable. We anticipate both experimental conditions to lead to decreased procrastinating behaviour scores relative to the control condition, with the decrease being more pronounced in the personal meaning relative to the positive feelings group. 

If there is a significant effect of group, two tailed t-tests will be conducted to see how the groups differ. 


6) Exploratory tests
To examine how the effectiveness of the intervention is affected by other factors, we will run an ANCOVA for each of the two experimental intervention groups (i.e. personal meaning and positive affect). For each ANCOVA, the dependent variable will be procrastinating behaviour score, and the within-subjects factor will be time (pretest/posttest).

To assess whether intervention benefits are affected by the extent to which participants changed on the targeted dimensions (i.e. personal meaning and positive affect), we will include personal meaning (MILQ) and positive affect (PA) score, respectively, as covariates.

q21.value: We will use p < .05 with two-tailed tests.

q22.value:
Participants not fulfilling the inclusion criteria (see above) will be excluded. Specifically, we will screen out participants if any of the following are true: 
1) the participant identifies him/herself does not have an important goal that they are struggling with. 
2) the participant fails to follow instructions for the writing task. For example, participants in personal meaning group do not write about the meaningful aspects / value of their chosen goal. 
3) the participants does not complete both the initial and follow-up survey.

q23.value: Data will be analysed for its pattern of missingness. If Little’s MCAR test is not significant, and there is a small proportion of missing data, we will use listwise deletion. If, however Little’s MCAR test shows that the missing data is not completely missing at random, then missing data will be replaced using multiple imputation techniques.

registration_responses.q1: The role of goal meaning in behavioural procrastination
registration_responses.q2: Sisi Yang, Fuschia Sirois, Claudia C. von Bastian, Peter Totterdell
registration_responses.q3:
Procrastination is a form of self-regulation failure that reflects the prioritization of short-mood regulation over long-term goal achievement. Recent theory and research argues that an inability to regulate negative emotions in a healthy and nonself-defeating way plays a key role in understanding why people procrastinate (Sirois & Pychyl, 2013; Tice & Bratslavsky, 2000). Appraisal theories of emotion point out that one’s specific emotional reaction results from their subjective appraisal of an event (i.e. its meaning and significance of an event) rather than the event itself (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984; Scherer, 1988). An emotion regulation strategy known as cognitive reappraisal, a primary form of cognitive change, entails using cognitive and linguistic processes to reinterpret the meaning of a situation (Jazaieri et al., 2014), which is effective for downregulating negative emotions (Gross & John, 2003). Yet to date, there is little (if any) research directly testing whether cognitive reappraisal, interprets and assigns meaning to an event or potential stressor in particular, influences procrastination. In the present research we aim to address this gap by investigating how reappraising aversive tasks in light of personal meaning influences task-related emotions and subsequent behavioural procrastination.

Given that meaningfulness is strongly associated with positive emotions (Miao & Gan, 2018), in order to investigate the role of personal meaning on procrastinating behaviour but rule out the possibility that any effects from the meaning making manipulation are not simply due to increases in positive affect, comparing effect sizes of these two factors (i.e. personal meaning and positive emotions) on behavioural procrastination are needed.  

In addition, one common belief about the nature of procrastination is that it is linked to setting excessively high standards. Researchers have asserted that procrastination is closely correlated to perfectionism (e.g. Flett, Blankstein, Hewitt, & Koledin, 1992; Stöber & Joormann, 2001). More specifically, from a multi-dimensional perspective, a recent meta-analysis revealed that trait procrastination is positively associated with perfectionistic concerns, and negatively associated with perfectionistic strivings (Sirois, Molnar, & Hirsch, 2017). The question of whether perfectionism influences personal meaning or positive affect associated with goals and subsequent procrastination has, however, not been investigated.

If, however Little’s MCAR test shows that the missing data is not completely missing at random, then missing data will be replaced using multiple imputation techniques.

registration_responses.q8.question:
An experimental design will be used to test whether increased personal meaning of an aversive goal plays a role in subsequent behavioural procrastination. 
Participants will be randomized via Qualtrics to three groups: personal meaning group, positive affect group and control group.
Mechanisms of change (i.e. the levels of positive and negative affect, personal meaning of an aversive task) will be collected before the manipulation (pretest) and after manipulation (posttest) to obtain pre and post-test levels. Behavioural procrastination will be assessed 36-48 hours after the completion of the manipulation.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be invited by e-mail and online adverts to participate in a study about the subjective experiences of goal pursuit. Individuals who are working on an important goal, are aged 18 and over will qualify to participate. 

The initial survey 

Those who are interested in taking part, will be asked to click on a hyperlink to the Qualtrics survey web address, which will provide information about the study including the purpose of the study, the procedures participants would need to follow during the study, and what to do in case of problems or queries. After providing consent, participants will be asked to click the “I agree” button if they consent to participate.  

After linking to the online study via Qualtrics, all participants will be asked to complete a demographics questionnaire (age, gender, educational level and ethnicity) and the same set of baseline questionnaires (pretest). The baseline measures include 
The 9-item General Procrastination Scale (GPS-9; Sirois, Yang, & Van Eerde, 2019); the 5-item Personal Meaning Questionnaire (MILQ; Steger, Frazier, Oishi, & Kaler, 2006); the 10-item Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS; Mackinnon , Jorm, Christensen, Korten, Jacomb, & Rodgers, 1999); the 15-item Multidimensional Perfectionism Scale (MPS, Hewitt, Habke, Lee-Baggley, Sherry, & Flett, 2008).

Afterward, they will be instructed to list their most important current goal that they are struggling with. Specifically, in order to maximise the chance that they will procrastinate on a goal, we emphasised in the instructions that “it is better to list a goal that you are averse to and struggling with but need to complete.” 

In order to manipulate personal meaning, we will follow the procedures used in a study of expressive writing (King & Miner, 2000; Rubin, Boals, & Klein, 2010).
All participants will be randomized to either a personal meaning group, positive feeling group, or control group, and will complete condition-specific sets of statements.

Participants in the personal meaning group will be asked to think about the meaningful aspects of their intended goal, for example “Completing this goal will be valuable to how I see myself, because ______________________________.”
Participants in the positive affect group will be asked to write about something that made them happy, for example “Completing this goal will make me feel happy, because________________________.”
Participants in the control group will be asked to think about what they did yesterday, for example “I woke up to an alarm clock at________________________.”
Lastly, all participants will be presented with the meaning in life questionnaire (MILQ), the 10-item Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS) again. 
The follow-up survey

Participants will be contacted approximately 36-48 hours following their completion of the original survey via e-mail and invited to complete the follow-up survey. 
Their tasks will be to write down their chosen goal that they listed in the first part of the study, to complete a measure that assesses whether they procrastinated on their goal during the day following their participation, as well as to rate their emotional state (PANAS) and levels of personal meaning (MILQ). To measure procrastinating behaviour, participants will be asked to complete a grid that divides their past day (from 9am to 11pm) in 20-minute time intervals. A total of 42 intervals will be presented to participants at the same time. They will be asked to report what they were doing during each interval and indicate whether they were delaying or avoiding doing something they had intended to do once they recorded their activity at each interval. Any interval was indicated as “delay” will be counted as procrastination intervals and summed into reflecting the number of minutes spent procrastinating. This method of measuring behavioural procrastination was used in a previous study (Sirois & Giguère, 2018). Participants who successfully complete the initial and the follow up survey will have the option of being entered into a prize draw to win a £50 (or equivalent) Amazon voucher.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Personal meaning will be manipulated with a writing task, where participants will be asked to will be asked to think about the meaningful aspects of their intended goal.
Participants in the positive feeling group will be asked to write about how the goal makes them happy.
The control group will receive a writing task where they will be asked to think about their routines the previous day.

See below for the script of each writing task:

Personal meaning group: 
For this next task, we would like you to think about the meaningful aspects of your goal, that is the ways your goal may have value for you.   
Please complete at least two of the following statements listed below about your goal, thinking about how meaningful different aspect are. In completing these statements please write as much as you can about the personal meaning of your goal. A good answer should include at least 1-2 sentences per statement.
An example statement is: “Completing this goal will be valuable to how I see myself, because                                                          .”  

Positive affect group: 
For this next task, we would like you to think about the aspects of your goal that make you happy. 
Please complete at least two of the following statements listed below about your goal, thinking about how the goal can make you happy. In completing these statements please write as much as you can about the positive feelings of your goal. A good answer should include at least 1-2 sentences per question. An example statement is “Completing this goal will make me feel happy, because                    .”

Control group: 
For this next task, we would like you to think about what you did yesterday. 
Please complete at least two of the following statements listed below about how you spent your time yesterday. Please write as much as you can about what you did yesterday. A good answer should include at least 1-2 sentences per question. An example statement is “I woke up to an alarm clock at                        .”
registration_responses.q17.question:
The initial survey will include a question for each of the following: age, gender, educational level and ethnicity. Following this, participants will be asked to complete the following scales: the 15-item Multidimensional Perfectionism Scale (MPS), the 9-item General Procrastination Scale (GPS-9), the 5-item Personal Meaning Questionnaire (MILQ); the 10-item Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS). MPS and GPS-9 score will serve as covariates because these traits are thought to affect procrastinating behaviour (e.g. (Burka & Yuen, 1983; Flett, Blankstein, Hewitt, & Koledin, 1992; Lay, 1986; Seo, 2008; Sirois et al., 2017; Stöber & Joormann, 2001). 


In the follow up survey, we will measure behavioural procrastination as the outcome variable, by asking participants to complete a grid that divides their past day (from 9am to 11 pm) in 20-minute time intervals. Any interval that was indicated as “delay” will be counted as an incident of procrastination. All intervals marked as procrastination will be summed up to reflect the number of minutes spent procrastinating.
registration_responses.q18.question: We will use mean scores on the 9-items general procrastination scale (GPS-9), the personal meaning questionnaire (MILQ), the PANAS and the multidimensional perfectionism scale (MPS). The procrastination scores will sum the “delay “intervals into an index reflecting the number of minutes spent procrastinating.
registration_responses.q19.question:
1) Tests for normality

2) Descriptive analyses

We will use descriptive statistics on age, gender, education level and ethnicity in each group to summarize our sample data. A one-way ANOVA will be used to examine the distributions of age for each of the three groups to see whether the randomization was effective in balancing this variable across groups. When this is not the case, age will be used as a covariate in the hypothesis tests. 
A Chi-square test will be used to see whether gender/education level/ ethnicity affect personal meaning or positive affect in each group. 

3) Baseline equivalences
We will run a one-way ANOVA to see whether three groups are equivalent on key variables, including trait perfectionism, trait procrastination, personal meaning and positive affect. 

4) Manipulation check 
Two mixed ANOVAs will be conducted as manipulation checks to verify whether there is significant changes in personal meaning or positive affect from pretest to posttest within each of the respective experimental groups. In the first mixed ANOVA, the mean personal meaning score will serve as the dependent variable and condition (i.e. personal meaning / positive affects / control) will serve as the between-subjects independent variable, and time (pretest / posttest) will serve as within-subject factor. Likewise, the mean positive affect score will serve as the dependent variable in the second mixed ANOVA, condition will be the between-subjects, and time (pretest / posttest) will serve as within-subject independent variable.


5) Hypothesis tests
A one-way ANOVA will be conducted for the main hypothesis test. The summed procrastination score will serve as the dependent variable, and condition (i.e. personal meaning/positive affects/control) will serve as the between-subjects independent variable. We anticipate both experimental conditions to lead to decreased procrastinating behaviour scores relative to the control condition, with the decrease being more pronounced in the personal meaning relative to the positive feelings group. 

If there is a significant effect of group, two tailed t-tests will be conducted to see how the groups differ. 


6) Exploratory tests
To examine how the effectiveness of the intervention is affected by other factors, we will run an ANCOVA for each of the two experimental intervention groups (i.e. personal meaning and positive affect). For each ANCOVA, the dependent variable will be procrastinating behaviour score, and the within-subjects factor will be time (pretest/posttest).

To assess whether intervention benefits are affected by the extent to which participants changed on the targeted dimensions (i.e. personal meaning and positive affect), we will include personal meaning (MILQ) and positive affect (PA) score, respectively, as covariates.

question.value:
I manipulate the subject's self-esteem. The two levels of this categorical variable are danger to self-esteem and no danger to self-esteem.
I manipulate how optimism bias is measured. Either subjects are presented with the actual baserate of events or need to estimate the avreage likelihood of events.

Dependent variable: Optimism Bias, measured by the difference between likelihood estimates of others risks and likelihood estimates of owns risks (condition: base rate not given) or the difference between the given base rate and the likelihood estimates of owns risk (condition: base rate given).

I will use a two-way between subjects ANOVA to analyze my results. The manipulated, categorical independent variables are “self-esteem” and the “likelihood estimates of risks” whereas the dependent variable is the Optimism Bias.

q22.value:
Participants must be at least 18 years old and must not be students of the University of Erfurt. For some of the stimuli, people older than a specific age must be excluded from the data analysis. These stimuli are questions regarding a possible event taking place by a specific age. Furthermore, I will exclude participants who do not pass an attention check. To ensure attention and to detect careless responding, I will employ instructed response item suggested by Aust, Diedenhof, Ullrich and Musch (2013). The seriousness of participation will be assessed separately on a single page at the end of the survey. Participants will be asked whether they had answered in a serious manner, so that their responses could be used to investigate research questions on political attitudes. The wording of the question was: “It would be very helpful if you could tell us at this point whether you have taken part seriously, so that we can use your answers for our scientiﬁc analysis, or whether you were just clicking through to take a look at the survey?” Participants were able to choose one of two answers: “I have taken part seriously” or “I have just clicked through, please throw my data away.
To detect outliers we will use the MAD (Median Absolut Deviation) method according to Leys et al. (2013). All values greater or smaller than three absolute deviations from the median will be excluded. Furthermore, participants who need less than 8 minutes or more than 60 minutes will be excluded from the analysis.

See literature:
Leys, C., Ley, C., Klein, O., Bernard, P. & Licata, L. (2013). Detecting outliers: Do not use standard deviation around the mean, use absolute deviation around the median. Journal of Experimental Social Psychology, 49(4), 764 – 766.

Aust, F., Diedenhofen, B., Ullrich, S., & Musch, J. (2013). Seriousness checks are useful to improve data validity in online research. Behavior research methods, 45(2), 527-535.

attributes.title: The Contextualizing of Misogyny in Metal Culture
attributes.description: The aim of this research is to investigate the way in which men and women in metal culture contextualize, interpret, and affectively react to metal lyrics and imagery that depict violent acts towards women. Even though some subgenres of metal, such as brutal death metal and slam, almost exclusively depict acts of violence and sexual violence towards women in their lyrics and artwork, these are not subgenres that have strictly male fanbases. Female fans of these subgenres buy posters, albums, and shirts with graphic depictions of depraved acts towards their own gender. It is not clear how women in the brutal death metal and slam scenes resolve the conflict between their gender and the seemingly misogynistic depictions of violence in images and lyrics within those subgenres. This research will help us gain insight into this unique cultural environment to see the extent to which misogyny exists within metal extreme metal scenes.

q4.value:
1. The relationship between two types of sexism (hostile/benevolent) with enjoyment of three types of images (gory misogynistic, gory non-misogynistic, control) and lyrical preferences.  The main question here is whether or not liking misogynistic imagery and lyrics is associated with higher levels of misogynistic beliefs or not.  This question is exploratory so no hypothesis is being made.  
2. The relationship between two types of sexism perceptions in metal (first-hand to the self, general perception towards women) with the liking of misogynistic imagery and lyrics.  It is expected that there will be a negative relationship.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a within-subjects design where participants are exposed to three types of visual stimuli (3 gory non-misogynistic album covers, 3 gory misogynistic album cover, and 3 neutral control group album covers).  Metal fans differ in their liking of these types of album covers.  Participants will answer questions about how each album cover makes them feel,  and whether or not they would purchase music and merchandise depicting each image.  Afterwards, each participant will fill out the ambivalent sexism inventory, as well as two scales about perceived sexism in metal culture, and a lyrical preferences scale.  It is being investigated if liking misogynistic imagery and lyrics is associated with misogynistic idealogy or not.

q9.value: The nine blocks that make up the three conditions all appear in random order.  In addition, items in all scales have been randomized too.

The following are being measured: lyrical preferences, affective responses to album cover images, benevolent sexism, hostile sexism, and perceived sexism in metal culture.

Correlations will be run to explore the relationships between the variables, followed by ANOVAs to compare the means and pairwise comparisons to explore the differences between different levels of the variables.

Even though some subgenres of metal, such as brutal death metal and slam, almost exclusively depict acts of violence and sexual violence towards women in their lyrics and artwork, these are not subgenres that have strictly male fanbases. Female fans of these subgenres buy posters, albums, and shirts with graphic depictions of depraved acts towards their own gender. It is not clear how women in the brutal death metal and slam scenes resolve the conflict between their gender and the seemingly misogynistic depictions of violence in images and lyrics within those subgenres. This research will help us gain insight into this unique cultural environment to see the extent to which misogyny exists within metal extreme metal scenes.
registration_responses.q4:
1. The relationship between two types of sexism (hostile/benevolent) with enjoyment of three types of images (gory misogynistic, gory non-misogynistic, control) and lyrical preferences.  The main question here is whether or not liking misogynistic imagery and lyrics is associated with higher levels of misogynistic beliefs or not.  This question is exploratory so no hypothesis is being made.  
2. The relationship between two types of sexism perceptions in metal (first-hand to the self, general perception towards women) with the liking of misogynistic imagery and lyrics.  It is expected that there will be a negative relationship.

registration_responses.q8.question: This is a within-subjects design where participants are exposed to three types of visual stimuli (3 gory non-misogynistic album covers, 3 gory misogynistic album cover, and 3 neutral control group album covers).  Metal fans differ in their liking of these types of album covers.  Participants will answer questions about how each album cover makes them feel,  and whether or not they would purchase music and merchandise depicting each image.  Afterwards, each participant will fill out the ambivalent sexism inventory, as well as two scales about perceived sexism in metal culture, and a lyrical preferences scale.  It is being investigated if liking misogynistic imagery and lyrics is associated with misogynistic idealogy or not.
registration_responses.q12.question: Data collection is taking place through Qualtrics with human participants that are 18 years or older.  There will be no payment for participation.  Participants will volunteer to participate through metal music-themed social networking groups.  The study will take approximately one month for data collection and analysis.
registration_responses.q16.question: The type of album cover image is being manipulated.  There are three levels:  gory misogynistic, gory non-misogynistic, and a neutral, non-gory and non-misogynistic control.
registration_responses.q17.question: The following are being measured: lyrical preferences, affective responses to album cover images, benevolent sexism, hostile sexism, and perceived sexism in metal culture.

attributes.title: Biased processing of ambiguous social cues and interpersonal relationships

q1.value: Biased processing of ambiguous social cues and interpersonal relationships

q3.value:
(This study is a part of Lin’s dissertation work as well as a junior experimenter training program)
There is a need for human beings to maintain a stable interpersonal relationship(Baumeister and Leary, 1995), and the breakdown of such relationships is often considered the inducement of depression, especially for female patients (Hammen, 2018).
 Evidence indicates that the relationship between interpersonal stress and depression can be bidirectional; not only interpersonal stress can lead to depression, patients with depression and high-risk individuals are also more likely to trigger or engage in stressful interpersonal situations (i.e., stress generation) (Hames et al., 2013; Hammen, 2018). Depressed patients usually show an overly active feeling of self-deprecation in social interactions (Beck and Alford, 2009; Hames et al., 2013), which could contribute to the breakdown of social relationships. Neutral remarks are often perceived as criticism from others by depressed individuals; for example, if a colleague says “Be careful, don’t drop your cup”, a depressed patient might interpret it as “You are too stupid to hold a cup” (Beck and Alford, 2009). Moreover, depressed individuals tend to excessively seek assurances from others that they are lovable and worthy (Hames et al., 2013). They may keep seeking assurances from their significant others relentlessly even when such assurance has already been provided because they tend to question the sincerity of the assurance, which could make their partners feel annoyed and could ultimately lead to rejection (Hames et al., 2013). Hence, depressed patients and/or individuals at high risk of depression may be more likely to experience the dissolution of interpersonal relationships. 
   One possible cause of self-deprecation and excessive reassurance-seeking in interpersonal relationships may be the biased processing of ambiguous social cues in depressed patients and/or individuals at high risk of depression (Beevers et al., 2009; Smith et al., 2016). A tendency to perceive negative emotions in others may impact a depressed persons’ ability to effectively interact with social partners (Beevers et al.,2009). For example, depressed individuals display negatively biased identifications of ambiguous facial expressions (especially those mixed with sadness and happiness) (Beevers et al.,2009). A social partner, therefore, would have to be significantly more animated when expressing positive feelings to a depressed person, which could be tiring for the social partner and could lead to the erosion of the relationship (Beevers et al.,2009). In another study, Smith found that depression severity was associated with an increased tendency to perceive hostility in ambiguous interpersonal situations, consistent with the self-deprecation tendency as noted by Beck and Alford (2009). In a word, biased processing of ambiguous social cues may help explain why depression causes interpersonal stress. 
Surprisingly, although several studies have found that a positive association between depression and negative biases in the processing of social cues, there is little empirical data on the relationship between these biases and interpersonal relationships. If these negative biases do contribute to (interpersonal) stress generation, then individuals with stronger negative biases are likely to have poorer social relationships.
  The present study, therefore, aims to explore whether there is a relationship between the biased processing of ambiguous social cues and social relationships.  Specifically, we are interested in whether a hostile interpretation bias and a perception bias towards ambiguous smiles are associated with social outcomes (including social support, loneliness, social network size, and social network diversity).

q4.value: We hypothesize that individuals with stronger hostile interpretation bias and negative perception bias will have poorer social outcomes, including receiving less social support, increased loneliness, smaller social network size and lower social network diversity.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We have a correlational (cross-sectional) research design. We aim to examine the correlation between hostile interpretation bias and negative perception bias towards ambiguous smiles and social outcomes (primary outcomes; including social support, loneliness, social network size, and social network diversity). We will also explore whether hostile interpretation bias and negative perception bias are associated with depressive symptomatology and mood states (secondary outcomes) to replicate results from previous studies (e.g., Beevers et al., 2009; Smith et al., 2016).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from an online participant panel that consists of several chat groups in Tencent QQ (a popular IM software in China). Members of this participant panel are all college students from local universities. Participants will be paid ￥10-20 for their participation. The whole experimental procedure will be administrated online. We attempt to recruit 120 participants in 4 weeks.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 109. We will over-recruit ~10% (120 participants) to allow for missing data and exclusion.

q14.value: Our goal is to obtain .90 power to detect an effect size rho of .30 at the standard .05 alpha error probability (2-tail). We conducted an a priori power analysis using G*Power 3 and confirmed that a minimum sample size of 109 was required.

question.value:
In the present study, predictors are biases in the processing of ambiguous social cues:

Hostile interpretation bias will be assessed with the Ambiguous Intentions Hostility Questionnaire (AIHQ; Combs et al., 2007). The AIHQ is comprised of 15 negative situations that differ in terms of intentionality, 5 ambiguous, 5 intentional, and 5 accidental. Hostile interpretation bias will be indexed using the hostile attribution score on ambiguous situations (Combs et al., 2007).
Perception bias towards ambiguous smiles will be measured using a behavioral task developed for the current study. A similar but different task has been used in a previously registered pilot study (https://osf.io/c6e54/). Participants will be instructed to judge ninety images of smiling faces as friendly/happiness or contemptuous/hostile. Thirty of these faces are unambiguously positive, and thirty are unambiguously contemptuous. These faces are selected from the Taiwanese Facial Expression Image Database (Li-Fen Chen and Yu-Shiuan Yen, 2007). Positive smiling faces and contemptuous faces are paired with each other to generate ambiguous smiling faces (i.e., 50% friendly/happiness - 50% contemptuous/hostile). We will use the proportion of negative identification of smiles as the index of the negative perception bias:
negative identification % = number of negative identification trials/(number of total ambiguous trials – number of missed ambiguous trials) * 100%

Our primary outcomes (variables for confirmatory analysis) are social outcomes including:
Social Support Rating Scale (SSRS; Xiao, 1994). SSRS is the most commonly used measurement of social support in the Chinese population. It is a ten-item scale, and factor analysis reveal a tri-factor structure: subjective support, objective support, and utilization of support.
Chinese Version of the 8-item UCLA Loneliness Scale (ULS-8; Wu & Yao, 2008). In this study, we will use the Chinese version of ULS-8 to assess perceived loneliness.
Chinese Version of Social Network Index (SNI; Cohens et al., 1997). For the current study, we translated the SNI into Chinese to measure social network size and diversity.

Our secondary outcomes (variables for exploratory analysis) are measures of mood states:

Patient Health Questionnaire 9 (PHQ-9) (Kroenke et al., 2010) is a self-administered tool to screen depressive disorders. There are 9 items for respondents to rate based on their feelings during the past 2 weeks and the rating scale range from 0 to 3. Examiners measure depressive severity on a scale of 0-27 and scores more than 10 indicate clinically significant depression. 

Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS) (Watson et al., 1988) is a mood rating scale consists of two subscales named Positive Affect (PA) and Negative Affect (NA) including 10 items each. These two factors represent affective state dimensions: Low PA is uniquely associated with depression, while high NA is correlated with a variety of aversive mood states (Crawford and Henry, 2004). In the present study, participants will be asked to indicate to what extent they felt according to mood states right now and rating from 1 (very slightly or not at all) to 5 (extremely).

Linear regression analyses will be used to examine the relationship between hostile interpretation bias and perception bias towards ambiguous smiles (predictors) and the social outcomes (SSRS, ULS-8, social network size and diversity). All other analyses will be exploratory.

q21.value: We will adjust for multiple comparisons by calculating false discovery rate (FDR) adjusted p-values (Benjamini–Hochberg procedure). The alpha level for all statistical tests will be set at 0.05.

q22.value: Participants who have missing data in our primary outcome measures and the AIHQ or do not complete the perception bias task will be excluded. We will also use performance on the judgement of unambiguous facial expressions to determine the quality of data. Low quality data (those who fail in >33% QC checks) will be excluded. Outliers will be included in analysis.

q23.value: Participants who have missing data in our primary outcome measures and the AIHQ or do not complete the perception bias task will be excluded, but those with missing data in variables used in exploratory analyses (PHQ-9 and PANAS) will still be included in our confirmatory analysis.

q24.value: To replicate results from previous studies (e.g., Smith et al., 2016; Beevers et al., 2009), we will use bivariate correlation analysis to examine the relationship between mood variables (PHQ-9 and PANAS) and biases in the processing of ambiguous social cues.

attributes.title: The scope of phonological planning during online speech production

summary.value:
This is an amendment to the initial pre-registration for this project, which can be found at https://osf.io/gcjxr. 

This amendment concerns the procedures for Experiment 2: Delayed Condition. The procedure has been tested with four participants so far. Data will continue to be collected until we reach 50 eligible participants, as stated in the original experimental plan. Details are given in the attached document, along with other revisions concerning participant recruitment, participant exclusion, data exclusion, and the details of the statistical analysis to be performed on the final data set.

q3.value: This is a correlational study investigating the relationship between scores on two different measures of authoritarianism and tendency to think analytically. Previous studies have suggested that there is a relationship between these constructs, but we intend to provide more robust evidence that such a relationship exists.

q4.value: We hypothesize that those who score higher on measures of authoritarianism will score lower on a measure of analytic thinking. Additionally, we hypothesize that those who score highly on one measure of authoritarianism will also score highly on a second measure of authoritarianism.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is a within-subjects correlational design. All participants complete all measures, and all measures are presented in a randomized order, with item order randomized within measures.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Data has been collected on Qualtrics but has not been accessed by any researchers, including the user of the associated Qualtrics account.

question.value: Participants access the survey from SONA and complete the survey in exchange for course credit. The survey is administered in an online format via a link to Qualtrics. Participants must be 18 years old.

q13.value: A target of 200 participants was set as an arbitrary benchmark for adequate sample size.

q15.value: Data were collected up to the end of the window for participation on SONA at the end of the semester.

question.value: None

A general measure of authoritarianism, the Aggression-Submission-Conventionalism scale (ASC), was utilized. Right-wing authoritarianism was also measured via the Right-Wing Authoritarianism scale (RWA). In addition, the long-form Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT) was used to measure analytic thinking.

All items in each measure will be combined to yield overall ASC, RWA, and analytic thinking scores. Items in the ASC scale will also be combined into the 3 subscales that exist within the scale to yield aggression, submission, and conventionalism scores. Scores on the RWA and on the ASC and its subscales will be calculated as means. Scores on the CRT will be calculated two ways: counts of the number of correct responses and counts of the number of incorrect but intuitive responses.
Simple bivariate correlational tests will be done comparing ASC, RWA, and CRT scores.

q21.value: The standard cutoff of p < .05 will be used to determine significance of correlations.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded if they do not answer a majority (half or more) of questions for any measure, or if they note in the comments that their data should be excluded for any reason.

q23.value: If a majority of any measure has not been completed, the data for that participant will be excluded.

q24.value: Additional analyses will be conducted comparing the scores of men and women on each measure, as well as analyses controlling for ideology. These will be done on an exploratory basis.
